description:
Drosophila ananassae is a species of fruit fly that belongs to the genus Drosophila. It is commonly known as the pineapple fruit fly or the Hawaiian fruit fly.

Drosophila ananassae is a small insect, typically measuring around 2-3 millimeters in length. It has a yellowish-brown body with dark-colored eyes and wings. The species is widely distributed across tropical and subtropical regions, including Southeast Asia, Africa, and parts of the Americas.

Drosophila ananassae is an important model organism in the field of genetics and evolutionary biology. It has a relatively short life cycle, with the complete development from egg to adult taking approximately 10-12 days under optimal conditions. The species is known for its high genetic diversity and the presence of various chromosomal inversions, which make it a valuable tool for studying population genetics and evolutionary processes.

Drosophila ananassae is commonly found in association with ripe and fermenting fruits, where it lays its eggs. The larvae feed on the decaying fruit, contributing to the decomposition process. The species has been used extensively in research studies, particularly in the areas of developmental biology, behavior, and the genetic basis of various traits.

Overall, Drosophila ananassae is an important model organism that has contributed significantly to our understanding of the genetic and evolutionary mechanisms underlying various biological processes.
